msItemStruct.colophon: 書写奥書は無し。巻九・十に文亀三年（1503）の吉田兼倶本奥書あり。

filiation.p: 本写本は、『延喜式』諸本の中でも全巻が揃う数少ない新写本の一本であり、善本として知られる。
系統としては一条家本を親本としたと推測されるが、本写本の書写段階で欠落していた巻十三については版本によって補填されている。巻十三は九条家旧蔵巻子本が現存諸本の祖本となる。
なお、『延喜式』の原本は現存せず、古写本として東京国立博物館所蔵九条家旧蔵巻子本、天野山金剛寺所蔵本等が現存するが、全巻すべてが揃うものはない。
本写本以外の主要写本には、京都国立博物館所蔵本（京都博物館本）・京都大学附属図書館所蔵近衛家旧蔵本・天理大学附属天理図書館所蔵本（梵舜本・梵舜別本）・宮内庁書陵部所蔵本（ 壬生家旧蔵本・藤波家旧蔵本）・国立公文書館所蔵本（紅葉山文庫旧蔵慶長写本・林家旧蔵本）等がある。

history.summary: 土御門家旧蔵→田中教忠氏が収集→孫の田中穣氏が『田中教忠蔵書目録』を私家版として発行→国に譲渡→歴博に移管
history.origin: 土御門泰重が元和3年（1617）から4年頃に、一条家所蔵の写本（現存せず）を借用して転写させたものである。泰重の孫泰福が、巻五十の末尾に泰重真筆である旨の識語を記す（実際には泰重の筆はごく一部にとどまる）。また、巻五十後表紙見返しに田中教忠による貼紙がある。
history.provenance: 幕末ないし明治初年に田中教忠が入手する。教忠孫の田中穣が1988～1989年に他の教忠収集コレクションとともに国に譲渡。

supportDesc.condition: 全巻揃っている。とくに致命的な落丁や虫損は、土御門本自体には基本的に見られない。

binding.p: 渋染栗皮色の表紙。まず左下に墨書で巻数、左上に胡粉で延喜式と直書きされており、そして左下に胡粉で巻数が上書きされている。右上には、巻の内容を表す式名やその略称が胡粉で直書きされている。表紙の心紙には楮紙でできた反故紙が使用されている。巻十三以外に押し八双あり。

projectDesc.p:
本プロジェクトは、日本古代の法制書『延喜式』の国際的流通と、研究における高度な利活用を目的としている。作成されたデータは学術基盤として広く共有されることを前提としており、国際標準であるTEI P5ガイドラインに準拠することで、国内外の多様な研究プラットフォームとの連携およびデータ流通に対応する。
データ作成の経緯として、基幹研究プロジェクト「異分野融合による総合書物学の構築」（2016～2021）段階においてTEI/XML基盤の設計を行い、校訂文、現代語訳、英訳の三種を中核とするデータ構築を進めた。これらのデータは、Web閲覧システム「デジタル延喜式」の基盤としても活用されており、年次計画に基づき各巻のデータを順次公開している。
現在の基幹研究プロジェクト「延喜式のデジタル技術による汎用化」（2022～）の段階では、基本データの整備を継続しつつ、新たな活用モデルを試験的に構築している。具体的には、taxonomy や standOff 等による多角的な情報活用モデルの構築と、measure や属性情報を基盤とした物品情報の可視化を実現する試みである。これらを通じ、本データが次世代の学術資源として持ち得る可能性を検討・実装している。
複雑な史料構造をTEIへ変換する過程で対応しきれなかった事項は多々あるものの、日本史資料のマークアップにおける先行事例が少ない現状に鑑み、現時点での到達点を提示している。今後の史料マークアップにおける参照モデルの一つとなり、次世代の史料デジタル化への寄与を目指している。

list.head: XMLファイル全体
list.item: 本データでは、校訂文・現代語訳・英訳のそれぞれを 個別の XML ファイルとして管理・公開している。各ファイルは、巻次およびデータ種別を明示したファイル名（例：校訂文 engishiki_v39、現代語訳 engishiki_v39_ja、英訳 engishiki_v39_en）によって構成されており、これによって各テクスト間の対応関係を識別することが可能である。
本テクストは、「デジタル『延喜式』」において定められた共通方針（下記 editorialDecl 参照）ならびに、公式サイトに掲載された全体凡例および各巻の個別凡例等に準拠する。

【語彙管理と情報の集積】taxonomy は、史料中の物品名を語彙項目として整理し、表記の統合を図るためのものである。各項目は、解説（label）に加え、文字種（漢字・かな等）およびデータ種（校訂文・現代語訳・英訳）ごとの表記情報を、listNym および nym を用いて構造的に保持している。また、語句間の関係性は、taxonomy の階層構造ではなく standOff 内の relation によって記述する。
【レイアウトの再現と table】 本文中の神名列記など、特定の視覚的段落表現を保持するため、table をレイアウト制御の手段として利用している。これは、空の cell や幅指定（rendition）を組み合わせることで、史料が持つ空間的な配置情報をデジタル文脈で表現するためのものである。
【データの統一性に関する注記】 日本史料への TEI 適用において先行事例が乏しいため、実験的なマークアップを含んでいる。巻次や史料の記述形式により、タグの適用範囲や属性の粒度に差異が生じている箇所があるが、これらについては各巻の個別凡例にて補足、あるいは将来的な一括処理を見据えた暫定的な記述としている。

list.head: 校訂文のXMLファイル
list.item: 【校異の記述と校訂根拠】諸本の異同は app 内の lem および rdg で示し、wit によって校訂根拠となる写本・版本情報を提示する。wit の対象は原則として写本・版本等に限定し、注釈書や他の歴史史料による知見は note 内に記述している。また、lem に示すべき写本が存在しない場合は cause を用い、校訂の根拠を明示する。
【採録範囲と個別凡例】本プロジェクトにおける校異の採録は諸本の網羅を目的とせず、校訂に実質的に資する写本・版本および傍書類に対象を限定している。採用する写本の種類や範囲は巻ごとに異なるため、詳細は各巻の個別凡例を参照されたい。
【傍書の扱い】傍書・傍訓・朱書・頭注といった文字周辺の注記情報は、note と place を組み合わせて記述するほか、独立した witness としても識別し、必要に応じて wit から参照可能としている。
【標注の扱い】標注を提示する際には、app をその記述単位として利用し、type="標注" を付与することで情報の性質を明示している。
【非文字単位・広範囲の注記】文字の配列や条文全体に関する注記など、文字単位の異同として処理できない情報については、app の構造を維持しつつ、note を用いて内容を記述する。校異の該当範囲が広範にわたる場合は、冒頭語句に anchor を配置し、note 内で「冒頭語句……末尾語句」と範囲を明記した上で、注記本文を記述する手法を採用している。

【物品情報の構造化（measure 等）】物品の数量・寸法を記述するため、measure、measureGrp、unit、note 等を使用している。ana（納税物区分）、commodity（品目の種類）、quantity（数量）、type（貢納量の規定か実数かの別）といった属性により、計量情報を厳密に定義している。品目名と総量を括る階層構造や、複数の単位を合算する measureGrp により、史料の計量記述を論理的に再現している。また、単位（unit）については unitRef を用い、unitDecl で体系的に定義された単位情報と紐付けている。なお、現段階での詳細な実装は巻24のデータに限定される。

list.head: 現代語訳のXMLファイル
list.item: note に type="summary" を付与し、条文概要を記述している。
ruby のマークアップは語句単位で実施している。

list.head: 英訳のXMLファイル
list.item: note に type="summary" を付与し、その条文の主題を示す簡潔なタイトルを記述している。
seg に rendition="#italic" を付与し、日本語音表記を表現している。

editorialDecl.p:
内膳式英訳凡例
・原文として『国立歴史民俗博物館研究報告』に掲載される土御門本を底本とする校訂文（小川宏和「『延喜式』巻三九の写本系統と「内膳司」本文校訂（稿）」『国立歴史民俗博物館研究報告』234、2022年）を用いている。条文番号・条文名は上記校訂文で用いられている虎尾俊哉編『訳注日本史料 延喜式』下（集英社、2017年）に従い、長文となる条文については、校訂文にあわせて便宜的に1、2、などと小見出しを付している。各条冒頭には、条文内容の把握の一助として条文概要を付している。
・英語圏における標準的な表示形式に従い、原文の注釈とローマ字は（ ）、割書は〈 〉、翻訳者の注は [ ] 内に入る。長い条文には字間を設けた。
・『延喜式』に記載された重量や寸法の算出には不明な点が多いため、本文中の度量衡は現代の寸法に換算していない。

div.p: Engi shiki , scroll39 〈Royal Family Register Office・Royal Meal Office〉
Royal Family Register Office

div.note: Age of Royal Recipients for Seasonal Clothing
div.p: Every year if a prince or princess reaches twelve years old , the Capital Office should report that information via a parallel memorandum ( i ) to the Ministry of the Royal Household in the twelfth month. Then the Ministry should send the memorandum to the Royal Family Register Office to check the list against their existing roster. After finishing all of these procedures, the Royal Family Register Office should return the memorandum to the Ministry. The prince or princess in question will receive seasonal clothing after the Council of State's order is issued in the following New Year.
div.note: In the Law on Personnel of the Yōrō Code, "prince" (王) and "princess" (女王) refer to the monarch's offspring of two through four generations removed.
Here, the premodern East Asian way of counting age, in which a person should be one years old at birth and gain another year at the New Year, is used to count to age twelve.
A parallel memorandum (移) is an official document format that is used to communicate between equal offices in the ritsuryō system.
Authorized Number of Princes or Princesses Receiving Seasonal Clothing
div.p: The authorized number of princes or princesses who can receive seasonal clothing is 429. If a vacancy is created due to a death of someone who has been receiving seasonal clothing, the person who is next in line should fill the vacancy. However, if a vacancy is created because someone is given a surname and made a commoner, do not fill that vacancy but promptly reduce the authorized number.
div.note: The original term for "princes and princesses" is shoō (諸王). I interpreted the term in this context to include both genders.
Seasonal clothing, jifuku (時服), was given twice a year.
Register of Princes or Princesses
div.p: Have the appropriate offices draw up two sets of a register of princes and princesses . The Royal Family Register Office should sign them, and after the Capital Office completes all the procedures, the Royal Family Register Office should keep one of the copies. After receiving the order of the Ministry of the Royal Household , which confirms that the princes or princesses have reached the eligibility age for receiving seasonal clothing, the Royal Family Register Office should check the information and report it to the Ministry.
div.note: The appropriate offices refer to The Capital Office and the Royal Family Office.
This section on the Royal Family Register Office deals with royal offspring of both female and male genders, so it is logical to translate shoō (諸王) here as princes and princesses.
This fu (符) refers to the order of the Ministry of the Royal Household rather than the order of the Council of State.
Princes or Princesses of the Same Generation with the Same Names
div.p: Regarding royal offspring who hold court posts and receive seasonal remunerations based on their posts: If there is a prince or princess who shares the same name with someone in the same generation, swiftly announce the situation and have his or her name changed. Then record on the register the new names of princes and princesses who receive seasonal remunerations and submit it to the appropriate ministry . Ensure, however, to write down the original name below the new name.
div.note: The ministry here is difficult to determine, but it is likely the Ministry of the Royal Household.
Princesses' Renumerations
div.p: On the eighth day of the first month, provide princesses with remunerations. Have the office in charge set up seats in the southern courtyard of the Shishinden , erect two ceremonial marquees in front of the Anpukuden , stack the remunerations for princesses at the south of the marker placed in the southern courtyard, and arrange the facilities inside the Shishinden. When the monarch arrives at the Shishinden, female chamberlains should lead female officials and take their seats. The officials of this Royal Family Register Office should escort the princesses and enter from the Gekka Gate. The princesses should take their seats under the ceremonial marquees first 〈the seating order should be determined by their generations removed from the monarch rather than their actual age. 〉 Then, the officials should move to the courtyard and take their seats as well. The manager of the Royal Family Register Office should raise the roster, saying "the offspring of Titled Prince such and such." Then princesses concerned should leave the seats under the ceremonial marquees by responding in the affirmative and take their seats in the southern courtyard. When everyone sits, the manager raises the roster and does a roll call. A princess who is called should respond in the affirmative, proceed to receive her remuneration, and then withdraw. The rest should follow suit. The amount of the remuneration given to each princess is 2 rolls of silk and 6 ton of silk wadding 〈The remuneration amounts provided at the Feast of the First Fruits should be the same.〉
div.note: The office in charge is the Bureau of Housekeeping, kamonryō (掃部寮).
The main reception hall in the Residential Palace.
Physicians' Hall.
The Royal Family Register Office consists of three management levels―a director, a manager, and two second level managers.
The original text uses the counter, ton (屯), which under the ritsuryō system equals to 450 grams.
Authorized Number of Princesses Receiving Renumerations
div.p: The authorized number of princesses who can receive remunerations is 262. A vacancy should be filled accordingly, but as being said in the previous entry, do not fill a vacancy if it is created because someone is given a surname and made a commoner.

div.note: Seasonal Clothing Provided to Princes and Princesses
div.p: The clothing provided for the spring and summer season to a prince or princess of two generations removed should be the following: 6 rolls of silk, 12 ku of silk yard, 18 rolls of hemp cloth, and 30 hoes. In the case of a prince or princess of four or more generations removed, follow the Laws on Remuneration. On the first month of the twentieth day, create a record of those who receive spring-summer clothing that year and send it to the Ministry of the Royal House. Do the same for autumn-winter 〈However, provide silk wadding instead of silk yard; and 5 hoes instead of 2 bars of iron.〉 Everybody who is titled to receive seasonal clothing should go to the Ministry of the Treasury to receive it; sending an agent to receive it is not allowed.
div.note: The ryō code defines 1 ku (絇) to be 16 "lesser ryō " (小両), so 12 ku should be 192 lesser ryō . 1 lesser ryō is 225 grams, so 12 ku is 43.2 kilograms.
Princesses' Renumerations at the Two Seasonal Court Banquets
div.p: Submit lists of attendees to the monarch in the morning of the two seasonal court banquets―one on the seventh day of the first month and one at the Great Harvest Rite―in order to provide princesses with remunerations.

div.note: Hirano Rite
div.p: Submit the list of attendees of the Hirano Rite―officials, princes, and princesses―to the Council of State.

div.note: Golden Light Sutra Lectures at Yakushiji
div.p: The Royal Family Register Office should select twenty to sixteen princes or princesses in advance when deciding the attendees of the Lectures on the Golden Light Sutra ( saishōe ) held at Yakushiji each year. These attendees must hold no official post, and their ranks should be sixth or lower. Then on the first day of the third month, the Office should submit the attendee list to the Council of State.
div.note: The original term is ōshi (王氏). Under the ritsuryō system, ōshi refers to royal offspring from the second generation and the fifth generation removed. Royal offspring without a specific clan name were also called ōshi .
A Buddhist temple built in 680 at the request of Sovereign Tenmu (r. 673-686). In 718, it was relocated to its current location in Nara as the capital was transferred to the Heijō Capital.
Princes or Princesses Taking a Tonsure
div.p: If a prince or princess takes a tonsure, stop providing him or her with seasonal clothing. Likewise, if a princess takes a tonsure, stop providing her with remunerations at the seasonal court banquets .
div.note: They refer to the two seasonal court banquets mentioned in the 8th entry.
Death of a Prince or Princess
div.p: If a prince or princess of the sixth rank or lower passes away, his or her household should report that to the Royal Register Office. And then the Office should immediately report that to the Ministry of the Royal Household.

div.note: The Size and Location of Land Supporting a Princess
div.p: The land supporting each princess should be 1 chō 〈It is located in the third block from the center in the northern area of the Left Capital.〉
div.note: A unit of area, approximately 1.2 ha.
Use of Unpaid Allowances
div.p: Special allowances to compensate for officials' extremely exhausting work should be used for minor repairment or for miscellaneous purposes at the Royal Family Register Office if there are vacant official posts, or if full-time officials or those serving in rotation are absent from work.
The Royal Meal Protocols

div.note: [Worker Payments for the Kasuga Spring Rite ]
div.p: Kasuga Spring Rite: 1 hiki of plain-weave silk ( ashiginu ) , 2 ton of silk floss 〈for one [Royal Meal] official in the color corresponding to his position〉, 4 tan of chōfu cloth 〈each of the eight cooks ( kashiwade ) are to be given 2 jō 1 shaku for outer robes 〉, 1 kin of safflower 〈a suitable amount for dying the cooks'cloth〉, 1 tan of dark blue cloth 〈an amount for the female servants' ( nyotei ) trains 〉, 6 tan of shōfu exchange cloth 〈4 tan is for outer robes for each of the laborers ( shichō ) and the transporters ( tanfu ). The other 2 tan are for towels for the cooks and female servants.〉 As to the above, the various items are to be requested of the Royal Household Ministry in advance and they are to be sent from the Treasury Ministry. 〈However, see the Kami Affairs Protocols about the things for the kami's offerings.〉 The official is to summon cooks and laborers to the location where the rite is conducted and they present these items. Similar items are to be provided or made for the autumnal rite as well. 〈Transporters are to be requested at the time from the [Royal Household] Ministry.〉
div.note: The Kasuga Spring Rite was conducted for the tutelary deity of the Fujiwara, the Kasuga Deity, in the second month in Sōnokami District, in what is now the northern end of Nara Prefecture. In the days prior to the rite, Palace Kitchen Office officials ordered cooks, menial laborers, and serving women to come to prepare foods and other offerings.
Plain-weave silk, or ashiginu , appears throughout the Engi Protocols. This term refers to a general category of a plain-weave silk textile made of a thicker thread.
Chōfu tax cloth was a tax paid in kind item.
Outer robes made of hemp cloth, or hitoeginu , would be worn atop one's robes.

A train was fabric attached at the waist to trail behind the wearer. The female servants ( nyotei , jochō 女丁) were commoner women who performed a variety of tasks around the palace. These female servants came to work from different provinces.
Shōfu , also read as tani , refers to a hemp cloth given as payment or tribute that could be exchanged for other goods.
[The Ōharano Rite ]
div.p: The Ōharano Rite: this is the same as the Kasuga Rite.
div.note: The Ōharano Rite was held in the second month and eleventh month for the kami enshrined in Kyoto to protect the capital. When the capital was moved from Nara to Nagaoka in 784, the tutelary deity of the Fujiwara was made a protective deity of the new capital and palace, and when the capital was moved again to Kyoto in 794, it was enshrined as the protective deity of Kyoto.
[The Tsukihi Spring Rite ]
div.p: The Tsukihi Spring Rite: 2 high tables 〈to be provided by the Carpentry Bureau〉, 4 pieces of chōfu tax cloth 〈each piece to be 5 shaku in length and large enough to spread beneath the table〉, 8 Sue pottery tall dishes , 2 [Sue pottery] rounded square jars, 2 wooden rice containers, 1 kin of mulberry floss. 〈These are to be prepared by the Palace Storehouse Bureau.〉 The female chamberlains ( naishi ) are to request the various items above. As for the items being offered to the kami, the ingredients are to be taken out of the monthly provisions and prepared, arranged on the high tables, and sent to the Wardrobe Bureau. Similar items are to be provided or made for the autumnal rite as well.
div.note: This may have been a rite dedicated to the kami of the Mikushige Hall ( Mikushigedono ). This location was in the Jōgan Hall where the female royal secretaries ( nyokurōdo ) and others worked at sewing clothing. This kami may have been a kami of the Wardrobe Bureau.

Sue pottery is a type of stoneware fired above 1000°C, yielding a strong, gray pottery. Sue is unglazed, except for ashes that melt against its surface. Sue contrasts with another pottery type, Haji, which was unglazed and fired at a lower temperature. Both pottery types were regarded as utilitarian. The square jars mentioned here were a pottery made in Mino and Bizen provinces.
These tall dishes, or takasara , were bowls attached to stands that made them taller than other pottery dishes. A single “leg” mounted in the center supported the bowl.
Female chamberlains worked in the Back Palace serving the sovereign by conveying royal commands, managing lower level servants, and generally keeping things running.
[The Garden Kami ( sono no kami ) Rite ]
div.p:
The Garden Kami Rite 〈The same for both spring and autumn〉: 14 kami 〈2 for the Keihoku Garden, 3 for the Nagaoka Garden, 3 for the Nara Garden, 1 for the Yamashina Garden, 3 for the Hatsukashi Garden, 1 for the Naki Garden, and 1 for the administrative office managing the gardens .〉 As to the above, 1 seat is for a fifth ranking kami 〈for the Capital's Northern Gardens.〉 13 are sixth ranking.
Items for the fifth ranking kami: 3 shaku of five-colored plain-weave silk; 1 shaku of mixed color barkcloth ; mulberry and hemp floss, 1 ryō of each; 1 hoe; 3 to of white rice; 1 to of glutinous rice; soy and adzuki beans, 3 shō of each; 1 to of sake; 2 kin of abalone; 6 kin of bonito and dried meat or fish; 11 kin of various fermented fish ; 4 kin of wakame seaweed; 1 shō of salt.
Items for the sixth ranking kami: For each [kami] 1 shaku of five-colored thin plain-weave silk;1 shaku of mixed color barkcloth; 1 hoe; mulberry and hemp floss, 1 ryō of each; 1 shō of rice; 7 gō of sake; abalone, bonito, dried meat or fish, and wakame seaweed, 5 ryō of each; 7 gō of salt; 2 tan of yōfu tax cloth to pay for the norito prayers.
div.note: These were kami worshipped by the Royal Household Ministry. In this case, a rite was conducted specifically for the sono kami, or garden deities, that provided food for the sovereign.
The Keihoku and Naki Gardens are specifically named gardens, whereas Nagaoka, Nara, Yamashina, and Hatsukashi are places that contained gardens with kami to be worshipped for helping to provide food.

This ranking system used for the kami was the one used for officials, and there was a substantial difference between the fifth and sixth ranks. The sixth rank was a common for officials involved in government administration. This fifth ranking kami of the Capital's Northern Garden occupied a more important position in the ceremony than the sixth rankers.
Mixed-color barkcloth, or shizu , was made of paper mulberry, hemp, or other fibers woven in an irregular mix of colors.

Fermented fish was a precursor to what a modern reader would identify as sushi. It is made by cleaning a fish, salting it, and then packing the fish with cooked rice whereupon it undergoes a lactic acid fermentation process. Lactic acid bacteria and acetic bacteria transform the fish into a pungent, sour product.
This is a type of tax cloth that was originally paid in instead of corvée labor.
[The Amounts of Various Produce for Rites]
div.p:
The amounts of various produce for rites 〈The same in both spring and autumn〉:
The Sono Kara Kami rites, 3 koku ; Kasuga Rite, 4 koku ; Hirano Rite , 3 koku ; Ōharano Rite, 3 koku ; Memorial to Confucius ( Sekiten ) rite, 3 koku . 〈For types and amounts, see the Banquet Protocols.〉
div.note: The Hirano Rite was conducted for the kami of Hirano Shrine, which protected the maternal line of Kanmu Tennō, the royal house, and in particular, the crown prince. They also were tutelary deities of the Minamoto and Taira. The Four Seasons' Rites protocols lists four kami associated with Hirano Shrine.
[For the Sacred Meal with the Kami in the Sixth and Twelfth Months ( Kan'imake ) ]
div.p: For the Kan'imake in the sixth month 〈this is also to be done the twelfth month〉: Awaji salt, 2 shō ; Azuma abalone , 7 kin 5 ryō ; thinly sliced abalone, 6 kin 10 ryō ; bonito, 5 kin ; 6 dried sea bream; 30 dried horse mackerel; fermented abalone, boiled salt-boiled sweetfish , and hishio crucian carp, 2 shō of each; 4 sea bream lightly cured with salt; codium seaweed and wakame seaweed, 6 kin 10 ryō of each; dried jujubes, raw chestnuts, ground chestnuts , and water chestnuts, 2 shō of each. 〈In the twelfth month, tachibana oranges should be used in place of the water chestnuts.〉 4 hotogi jars ; 10 pots 〈4 large, 6 small〉; 8 torch bundles. The 2 offerings officials and the 6 cooks are to be given chihaya jackets made from 1 piece of bleached hemp cloth 〈length 8 shaku .〉
div.note: This occurs during the night of the Tsukinami Rite, which was done in the sixth and twelfth months. For the Tsukinami Rite, officials of government and shrines gathered for the reading of norito prayers followed by alms. These ingredients listed here would be consumed during the night as the sovereign communed with the kami.

Azuma abalone refers to abalone produced in the eastern provinces in a particular manner. Kiyotake Yūji points out that Azuma abalone specifically came from Awa Province, as well as Kazusa Province, so it was not simply “abalone of the east,” which encompassed a wider territory for “eastern” goods, but a specific regional preparation.
While there are no contemporary directions for making this preparation, the characters used here give us a hint. This ayu , or sweetfish, was liked boiled in saltwater to help preserve it.

Hishio was a fermented product made from grain and soybeans, similar to miso. The Banquet Protocols has an ingredient list for hishio : soybeans, rice (for inculcating, likely with kōji spores), glutinous rice, adzuki beans, sake, and salt. This was one of the four condiments, or shishu mono , served at banquets.
This is referring specifically to kachiguri , a chestnut preparation that consists of pounding dried chestnuts and removing the bitter skin.

Hotogi jars were a deep jar with a wide mouth. They could be made of earthenware, such as the ones sent from Yamato, Bizen, and Sanuki, which are recorded in the Accounting Bureau protocols ( Shukei 主計). Arai Hideki has proposed that earthenware hotogi jars were used for keeping things warm, while the sturdier Sue types would be used for transporting goods and storage.
A chihaya was a type of jacket or outer robe worn by workers. The cloth was made of hemp and bleached by sun exposure to become white.
[For the Great Harvest Rite ( Niinamesai ) Royal Meal ( kugo )]
div.p:
For the Great Harvest Rite royal meal: Salt, 2 shō ; Azuma abalone, 6 kin 10 ryō 2 bu 4 shu ; bonito, 5 kin ; fermented abalone, salt-boiled sweetfish, and hishio crucian carp, 2 shō of each; 4 delicious sea bream cured with little salt; codium seaweed and wakame seaweed, 6 kin 10 ryō 2 bu 4 shu of each; dried jujubes, 2 shō ; dried chestnuts, 2 shō ; ground chestnuts, 4 shō ; raw chestnuts, 1 to ; castanopsis nuts and water chestnuts, 4 shō of each; 4 tachibana oranges; 4 hotogi jars; hishio and oil, 5 shō of each.
The above is the items for the night rite's [royal meal].
div.note: From the establishment of the ritsuryō system, the Great Harvest Rite was performed in the eleventh month over a two day period. In the afternoon, the officials conducted a large ceremony to present offerings ( hanpei ) to 304 kami at designated shrines throughout the Kinai. The Great Harvest Rite was held on a tiger day, when the sovereign consumed the newly harvested grains, as well as the foods listed here, and communed with the kami.
[For the Gesai Feast Served at the Conclusion of Great Harvest Rite Purifications]
div.p:
Rice, 2 to ; glutinous rice, 2 to ; dehydrated glutinous rice and foxtail millet, 2 shō of each; 10 stalks of glutinous rice; wheat, 4 shō ; soybeans, 2 shō 2 gō ; adzuki, 1 shō 6 gō ; sesame seeds, 2 shō 8 gō ; perilla seeds, 3 shō ; clear sake and cloudy sake, 1 to of each; vinegar and hishio , 5 shō of each; salt, 2 shō ; Azuma abalone, 1 kin 10 ryō 2 bu 4 shu ; thinly sliced abalone, 13 kin 5 ryō 1 bu 2 shu ; Oki abalone , 2 kin 5 ryō 1 bu 2 shu ; boiled bonito and sazae sea snail, 13 ryō 1 bu 2 shu of each; squid, 10 ryō 2 bu 4 shu ; dried whole fish and fowl, 5 shō ; nori, 10 ryō 2 bu 4 shu ; codium seaweed and wakame seaweed, 6 kin 10 ryō 2 bu 4 shu ; dried ginger, 3 ryō ; 1 basket of dried sorrel; dried jujubes, 2 shō ; ground chestnuts, 6 shō ; dried chestnuts, 2 shō ; raw chestnuts, 2 to 2 shō 8 gō ; 2 strings of dried persimmon; castanopsis nuts, 4 shō ; water chestnuts and lotus seeds, 2 shō of each; 24 kage of tachibana oranges and 10 tachibana orange branches ; 10 plain chests; 19 large Sue pottery dishes; 12 [Sue pottery] bucket dishes ; 26 [Sue pottery] bowls; 7 [Sue pottery] large jars; 6 [Sue pottery] rounded square jars; 10 vinegar jars; 12 washing bowls; ash-fired hotogi jars and mortars, 8 of each; 30 Haji pottery roasting pots; large and small washing bowls, 4 of each; 8 large [Haji] dishes; 12 snuffers; 10 [Haji] hotogi jars; 50 pots 〈12 large, 38 small〉; 42 loads ( hyō ) of Kashiwa oak leaves . 〈These are to be all requested at one time and used over the seven royal banquets .〉
The above section is the items for the Gesai [conclusion of purification rites] . However, the various vessels are to be used throughout the year on the seven royal banquets. 〈Similar items are to be provided, which are listed in the next clause.〉
div.note: By modern standards, this sake was likely not particularly clear; however, it had been strained more times than the cloudy sake to remove sediment.

Oki abalone were only consumed by those of fifth rank and above, making it higher status product. Possibly because of this, Oki abalone had a prestige that led to its wider consumption even into the medieval period.

It is not clear what this counter, kage , means here in the Tsuchimikadobon manuscript. The use of the kage counter implies that this counter might not actually refer to tachibana oranges. The Kujōkebon manuscript explains in a note that these were straw wreaths decorated with orange blossoms.
Oke were round vessels made of thin strips of wood or hemp, so it is possible that these bucket dishes, okezara , were pottery with a woven, bucket-like design.
Oak leaves were used in plating and presenting food, such as when they were woven together to create dishes.

The Seven Royal Banquets were banquets attended by his majesty ( sechie ): New Year's Royal Banquet, White Horse Royal Banquet, Song and Dance Royal Banquet, Fifth Day Royal Banquet, Seventh Month Seventh Day Royal Banquet, Double Yang Banquet, and the Warmth of Sake Royal Banquet.
This gesai marked the completion of the Great Harvest Rite.
[For the Warmth of Sake Royal Banquet ( Toyo no Akari no sechie ) ]
div.p:
Rice, 1 to ; glutinous rice, 2 to ; cooked and dried foxtail millet, 2 shō ; wheat, 4 shō ; sesame seeds, 2 shō 8 gō ; perilla seeds, 3 shō ; salt, 2 shō ; Azuma abalone, 6 kin 10 ryō 2 bu 4 shu ; bonito, 5 kin ; codium seaweed, 6 kin 10 ryō 2 bu 4 shu ; wakame seaweed, 10 ryō 4 bu 8 shu ; fermented abalone, salt-boiled sweetfish, and hishio crucian carp, 2 shō of each; 1 basket of dried sorrel; dried jujubes and dried chestnuts, 2 shō of each; ground chestnuts, 4 shō ; raw chestnuts, 1 to ; 2 strings of dried persimmon; castanopsis nuts and water chestnuts, 4 shō of each; 24 kage of tachibana orange [blossom wreaths], tachibana orange [blossoms] attached to 10 branches [per wreath]; 10 plain chests; 19 large Sue pottery dishes; 12 [Sue pottery] bucket dishes; 26 [Sue pottery] bowls; 7 [Sue pottery] large jars; 6 [Sue pottery] rounded square jars; 10 [Sue pottery] vinegar jars; 12 washing bowls; ash-fired vessels and mortars, 8 of each; 30 Haji pottery roasting pots; large and small [Haji] washing bowls, 4 of each; 8 large [Haji] dishes; 12 [Haji] snuffers; 10 [Haji] hotogi jars; 8 torch bundles; charcoal, 4 koku ; and firewood, 600 kin . The 2 [Royal Meal] officials making the offerings and the 6 cooks should receive outer robes and chihaya jackets.
The above is the items for the Warmth of Sake Royal Banquet.
div.note: For this banquet, royals and officials processed into the Burakuin Hall, where after taking down the text for proclamations, the Royal Meal Office brought the royal meal to the sovereign. There would be rounds of drinking. The translated name of the banquet here refers to the glow or warmth to the skin that follows drinking. Different groups would offer up examples of regional song and dance, followed by emoluments for service.
[For the Warmth of Sake Royal Banquet, cont.]
div.p:
Salt, 2 shō ; Azuma abalone, 6 kin 10 ryō 2 bu 4 shu ; bonito, 5 kin ; codium seaweed and wakame seaweed, 6 kin 10 ryō 2 bu 4 shu of each; fermented abalone, hishio crucian carp, and salt-boiled sweetfish, 2 shō of each; 1 basket of dried sorrel; ground chestnuts, 4 shō ; raw chestnuts, 1 to ; castanopsis nuts, 4 shō ; water chestnuts, 2 shō ; 2 tachibana oranges; 10 plain chests; 19 large Sue pottery plates; 12 [Sue pottery] bucket dishes; 24 [Sue pottery] bowls; 7 [Sue pottery] large jars; 6 [Sue pottery] ceramic boxes; 10 [Sue pottery] vinegar jars; 12 [Sue pottery] washing bowls; 8 [Sue pottery] mortars; 30 Haji pottery roasting pots; large and small [Haji] washing bowls, 4 of each; 8 large [Haji] dishes; 12 [Haji] snuffers; 10 [Haji] hotogi jars; 8 torch bundles; charcoal, 4 koku ; 60 kin of firewood.
The queen-consort's ( chūgū ) Warmth of Sake Royal Banquet amount is the same as the above .
div.note: The queen-consort did not attend this banquet. It is unclear what this might mean in this context. Typically the sovereign and queen-consort received the same amounts as royal meals.
[ For the Lectures on the Golden Light Sutra Rite ]
div.p: For the Lectures on the Golden Light Sutra Rite: 6 koku 5 to 4 shō 5 gō of various produce [are allocated] for the Banquet Office. The 2 [Royal Meal] officials and the 4 cooks preparing the offerings to the buddhas and kami are to receive 1 ryō of chōfu cloth for outer robes 〈from that 1 ryō , 2 jō 1 shaku is to be set aside〉. [For the cooks,] 4 pieces of chōfu tax cloth 〈the length is to be 8 shaku each, and the four cooks are to receive [1 jō each] for a chihaya jackets.〉
div.note: This was an event held in the New Year over five days to protect the realm and sovereign. From the eighth day to the fourteenth day, the palace held lectures on the Golden Light Sutra.
[For the Seven Temples'Seventh Month Fifteenth Day Obon Rite ( urabon ) ]
div.p: For the Seven Temples'Seventh Month Fifteenth Day Obon Rite: various produce, 3 koku 2 to 〈Each temple receives 4 to 5 shō 7 gō 〉; fruits, 2 koku 4 to 3 shō 〈Each temple receives 3 to 4 shō 7 gō .〉
div.note: This rite was held for the memory and repose of the deceased by making offerings to the Sangha. The palace would send these offering to the monks at seven temples: Tōji 東寺, Saiji 西寺, Saidera 佐比寺, Yasakadera 八坂寺, Nodera 野寺, Izumodera 出雲寺, and Shōshinji 聖神寺. The Banquet Office was the lead on this event.
[ The Three Royal Banquets of the New Year ]
div.p:
For the royal meal at various royal banquets 〈the queen-consort's amounts are the same, and the following are to be provided to lower rankers.〉 The three royal banquets of the New Year: rice, 3 to ; glutinous rice, 4 to 6 shō 5 gō ; 15 sheaves of glutinous rice on the stalk; dehydrated glutinous rice, 3 shō ; dehydrated foxtail millet, 6 shō ; wheat, 1 to 2 shō ; perilla seeds, 9 shō ; sesame seeds, 8 shō 4 gō ; soybeans, 3 shō 3 gō ; adzuki beans, 2 shō 4 gō ; clear sake, cloudy sake, vinegar, and oil, 1 to 5 shō of each; hishio , 3 to ; salt, 6 shō ; Azuma abalone, 8 kin 4 ryō ; Oki abalone, 11 kin 1 ryō ; simmered bonito, 4 kin 2 shō ; sazae sea snail, 4 kin 3 ryō ; nori, 1 kin ; dried ginger, 1 kin ; dried jujubes, 3 shō ; ground chestnuts, 9 shō ; raw chestnuts, 6 to 4 shō 2 gō ; 6 strings of dried persimmon; castanopsis nuts, 6 shō ; water chestnuts, 3 shō ; 36 tachibana orange [blossom wreaths with blossoms] attached to 15 branches; fallen tachibana oranges , 1 to ; 5 long chests; 18 roasting pots; bamboo, 3 bundles; 12 koku of charcoal for the kitchen; 1800 pieces of firewood. The 40 cooks 〈30 for the sovereign, 10 for the queen-consort〉 preparing the offerings are to each receive 1 ryō of dark blue cloth for outer robes. (This cloth will be used over the three banquets.〉 Each of the thirty cooks on leave ( kaban no kashiwade ) at each royal banquet is limited to two days and receives 2 shō of rice per day. 〈Other royal banquets are to follow this as well.〉
The above items for the three days of royal banquets are to be presented at one time and then divided up according to each banquet day. The items for the Grand Archery Meet ( jarai ) come from this list as well. Additionally, the side dishes for the archery matches ( noriyumi ) on the eighteenth day are to be prepared and served to the nobility and Inner Palace Guards assistant commander ( konoe jishō ).
div.note: The “New Year” does not refer to a single day at the start of the lunar calendar year, but a series of celebratory days that marked the beginning of the New Year. The three banquets of the New Year were the New Year's Royal Banquet on the first day of the first month, White Horse Royal Banquet on the seventh day, and the Song and Dance Royal Banquet on the sixteenth day.
This might refer to tachibana gathered from the ground.
The Grand Archery Meeting happened the day after the Song and Dance Banquet.
[For Royal Meals in the New Year]
div.p:
Daikon radish, melon miso pickle, melon sake lees pickle, venison, boar meat, salt-pressed sweetfish, salt-boiled sweetfish, 7 glazed Sue pottery dishes, 1 high table 〈length of 3 shaku 5 sun , width 1 shaku 7 sun , height 4 shaku .〉
The above is to be prepared for the royal meals from the first day [of the New Year] through the third day.

div.note: [For Making Lye Mochi ( chimaki ) in the Third through Fifth Months]
div.p:
2 koku of glutinous rice for lye mochi 〈2 shō 5 gō per day〉; cowpeas, 6 to 〈6 gō 6 shaku per day〉; ramie, 2 large kin ; 60 loads of firewood 〈to be purchased with cash〉; 60 sheaves of wild rice 〈to be purchased in kind.〉
The above is to be prepared for [royal] meals from the third month tenth day to the fifth month thirtieth day.
div.note: Chimaki is a glutinous mochi dumpling wrapped in straw or leaves and cooked in lye water. The lye water is made by cooking plant ashes. The Banquet Protocols says that lye mochi were served at the Fifth Month Fifth Day Royal Banquet. Here the rice might have been combined with cowpeas, wrapped in ramie, and then cooked.
[ Fifth Month Fifth Day Royal Banquet ]
div.p: Fifth Month Fifth Day Royal Banquet: rice, 1 to 3 shō ; glutinous rice, 1 to 7 shō ; 5 sheaves of glutinous rice 〈for pounded roasted rice 〉; dehydrated glutinous rice and foxtail millet, 2 shō of each; soybeans, 2 shō ; wheat, 4 shō ; sesame and perilla seeds, 4 shō of each; sake, 1 to ; vinegar and oil, 5 shō of each; hishio , 1 to ; salt, 2 shō ; dried whole fowl, 4 kin ; Azuma abalone, 1 kin 10 ryō ; Nagato abalone, Awa abalone, Izumo abalone, and Oki abalone, 2 kin 5 ryō of each; 2 salmon; squid, 1 kin 5 ryō ; boiled bonito and sazae sea snail, 13 ryō of each; dried whole fish and fowl, 5 shō ; nori, 5 ryō ; codium seaweed, 1 kin 5 ryō ; dried chestnuts, 1 to ; raw chestnuts, 1 to 7 shō 4 gō ; 2 plain wood boxes ( arahako ); raw silk, 2 bu 4 shu ; 10 bundles of green wild rice ; 1 bundle of bamboo; charcoal, 4 koku ; firewood, 60 kin . Each of the 40 cooks 〈30 for the sovereign and 10 for the queen-consort〉 preparing the offerings each receives 1 ryō of dark blue cloth for outer robes.
div.note: This banquet was also called Tango no sechie . Prior to the banquet, there were mounted archery demonstrations and offerings of sweet flag ( ayamegusa ), as well as music. Participants would also attach the herb to their person. The Gishiki says that the Royal Meal Office was to serve the sovereign at the Hour of the Horse (11-1), and then the Banquet Agency and the Crown Prince's Office would serve them and present gifts, followed by the setting out of sweet flag tables. There was also a presentation of horses from the royal stables and ranches and horse-racing.
This refers to newly harvested rice that is roasted with the husk and outer layers on that is pounded to remove the grain.
Wild rice, or makomo , is an East Asian variety of rice with an edible stem and grain. Here this would be referring to bundles of green wild rice stems.
[ Seventh Month Seventh Day ]
div.p: Seventh Month Seventh Day [royal banquet]: rice and glutinous rice, 6 shō of each; dehydrated glutinous rice, 8 to ; dehydrated foxtail millet, 3 shō ; common millet and wheat, 6 shō of each; adzuki beans, 1 shō ; sake, 2 to ; vinegar and oil, 5 shō of each; hishio , 1 shō ; salt, 1 shō ; Azuma abalone, 1 kin 10 ryō ; Oki abalone, 2 kin 5 ryō ; squid and sazae sea snails, 1 kin 5 ryō of each; boiled bonito, 13 ryō ; dried whole fish and fowl, 5 shō ; nori, 4 ryō ; codium seaweed, 1 kin ; 1 stove; charcoal, 4 koku ; firewood, 600 kin .
div.note: The seven month seventh day was designated as a day to hold a royal banquet, but the theme of that banquet changed over time. By the time Fujiwara no Tadahira was compiling the Engi Protocols, a trend had emerged of officials selecting wrestlers for demonstrations at the end of the seventh month and then a sumo banquet for officials was happening within the first half of the eighth month. This banquet in the eighth month was a kyō 饗 for officials that participated in the demonstrations, not a royal banquet or sechie 節会, which would have been attended by the monarch.
[ Ninth Month Ninth Day [Double Yang] Royal Banquet ]
div.p: Ninth Month Ninth Day Royal Banquet: rice, 2 to 3 shō ; 5 sheaves of glutinous rice; dehydrated glutinous rice, 1 to ; dehydrated foxtail millet, 2 shō ; wheat and sesame seeds, 4 shō of each; soybeans, 2 shō ; adzuki beans, 1 to ; perilla seeds, 6 shō ; sake, 1 to ; vinegar and oil, 5 shō of each; hishio , 1 to ; salt, 2 shō ; Azuma abalone, 1 kin 12 ryō ; Oki abalone, 2 kin 5 ryō ; squid, 1 kin 5 ryō ; boiled bonito and sazae sea snail, 13 ryō of each; salt-pressed sweetfish and dried whole fowl, 8 ryō of each; dried whole fish and fowl, 5 shō ; nori, 5 ryō ; codium seaweed, 1 kin 5 ryō ; charcoal, 3 koku ; 600 kin of firewood.
div.note: The ninth month ninth day had a Chrysanthemum Feast ( Kikuka no en 菊花宴) inspired by a Chinese gathering. This event happened in the Shinsen'en 神泉苑 park where officials were furnished with paper, ink, and the supplies needed for poetry composition. A boat was provided for rides. There was drinking and dance performances, as well as proclamations issued by the throne.
[Monthly Provisions for Offerings to the Royal Table]
It may be that this was one type of foxtail millet to be made into mochi. This would be read as “ awa no mochi .” There are other possible interpretations, such another type of millet or sorghum.
The Banquet Protocols describe ame as being made from glutinous rice and sprouted wheat, which could be used to make brown rice syrup.

It is difficult to know what this term means. The first character 搗 refers to mashing or grounding, and we see it often around chestnuts. The second character 糟 is for sake lees, which is the mash leftover after sake is strained. This was served to the sovereign and queen-consort on a regular basis, although it was switched with other types during certain banquets, like the ones in the New Year.
This mixture, a type of cloudy sake, was made from sake lees or mash from the same royal sake offered to the sovereign on a daily basis.
This can be read as hishio that has been wrung out, separating a liquid and leaving the mash of beans and grains behind.
div.p: dried meat ( hojishi ), 9 kin ; dried whole fowl and salt-pressed sweetfish, 16 kin 8 ryō of each; Azuma abalone, 45 kin ; thinly sliced abalone, 11 kin 4 ryō ; Oki abalone, 45 kin ; hishio abalone, 21 jō ; bonito, 225 kin ; boiled bonito and sea cucumber, 8 kin 4 ryō of each; octopus and squid, 23 kin 4 ryō of each; 45 salmon; dried whole fish and fowl, 4 to 5 shō ; kotsuo shark skin, 20 kin 13 ryō ; infusion bonito and salted sea cucumber innards, 4 shō 5 gō of each; various abalone from Awa Province, 23 kin 4 ryō ; pickled abalone innards, 2 to 3 shō 2 gō 5 shaku ; dried kue shark, 13 kin 8 ryō ; various fermented fish, 2 to 3 shō 2 gō 5 shaku ; tsuhikihachi fish skin , 21 kin 12 ryō ; 142 Noto Province Spanish mackerel; nori, 12 ryō ; codium seaweed, 2 kin 4 ryō ; arame kelp, 13 kin 8 ryō ; wakame seaweed, 22 kin 8 ryō ; gelidium seaweed, 4 kin 8 ryō ; glacilaria seaweed, 5 kin 4 ryō ; gloiopeltis seaweed, 12 kin ; campylaephora seaweed, 9 kin ;
div.note: This is read as kotsuo , which could be a type of shark. There is also a possibility that this could be a variety of flounder given the specification of skin and the fact that this is a food list; it would not make sense for shark skin to appear here.

This bonito was used for infusing soups, and we might consider this a precursor to katsuobushi , the bonito flakes used in making dashi today. This bonito was likely treated with salt and dried until hard.
The first character can be read as fugu , raising the possibility of this being a pufferfish.
div.p: leaf mustard and soybean-wakame seaweed mixture ( kuki ) , 4 shō 5 gō of each; 23 hishio melons; dried jujubes, 1 to 4 shō 2 gō 5 shaku ; ground chestnuts, 2 to 9 shō 3 gō 5 shaku ; dried chestnuts, 7 to 5 shō ; raw chestnuts, 2 koku 2 to 5 shō ; 29 strings of dried persimmons; castanopsis nuts, 4 to 5 shō ; walnuts, 1 to 5 shō ; 45 tachibana oranges; fallen tachibana oranges and water chestnuts, 2 to 2 shō 5 gō of each; lotus seeds, 1 to 5 shō 7 gō 5 shaku ;
div.note: The Banquet Protocols provides an ingredient list of soybeans and wakame, which were combined and fermented to make a condiment or side dish.
div.p: 7 shaku of silk 〈for wiping down the sovereign's dishes made with gold, silver, and red lacquer〉; 6 shō of lamp oil 〈for the Plating Station and the Offerings Station , 3 shō each〉; 450 pieces of bamboo for making chopsticks 〈90 pieces are to come from Otokuni Garden in Yamashiro Province and 360 are to come from Kasagi Garden in Sakaraka District.〉
div.note: The Plating Station ( Morimono dokoro ) was where food was arranged on the correct tableware before being carried to diners. The Offerings Station ( Shinmotsu dokoro ) aided in food preparation. It is important to distinguish these stations, as they represent two types. The Offerings Station was a relatively stable bureaucratic unit with a designated head, who was a noble of sufficient rank to enter the sovereign's living quarters. The Palace Kitchen ( Mizushi dokoro ) was another station in this category. However, the Plating Station was a temporary space set-up for an event with workers assigned for the occasion.
div.p: The above is the monthly provisions. For shorter months, this is to be decreased by one-thirtieth.

div.note: [For Stations]
div.p:
Charcoal, 1 koku 4 to 〈The Plating Station receives 4 to . The Offerings Station and Sweets Station each receive 5 to 〉; 3 torch bundles 〈1 torch bundle each for the Plating Station, Offerings Station, and Sweets Station〉; 120 pieces of firewood 〈The Grains Preparation Station and the Cooking Station are to receive 60 pieces each〉; the various ingredients for making various mochi ; 1 shō of amazake .
The above is the ingredients for one day.
div.note: The Sweets Station received fruits and nuts from gardens, which were inspected by the Banquet Office and then handled by the Royal Meal Office. The Grains Preparation Station was the site where grains like rice or millet are being cooked. The Cooking Station was not a permanent bureaucratic unit but instead a space wherever this cooking was occurring.

Mochi generally refers to glutinous rice that has been steamed, then pounded until smooth to make a dumpling. In the Heian period, mochi were flavored with savory elements, such as salty bean pastes and vegetables, as well as sweeter things. It was not only conceived of as a sweet like today.
Amazake is a sweet, non-alcoholic or low-alcoholic fermented drink made from rice and kōji.
[For Offerings in the Seventh, Eighth, Ninth, and Tenth Months]
div.p:
Mochi, fruits , and sweets , two willow boxes of each 〈Each to have a length of 1 shaku , and width of 9 sun 〉; plain wood boxes, 21 gō ; round chests, 24 gō ; 10 palm fronds .
The above is to be used for offerings from the seventh month seventh day through the tenth month.
div.note: This term, tametsu mono 甜物, refers to sweets. It appears in the Gishiki directions for the Daijōsai enthronement rites where it says that tametsu mono 多米都物 for that rite were to be “delicacies of various fruits, about a cart-load.”
Kashi includes fruits, nuts, and confections, but given the presence of fruits already, here it may refer to confections specifically.
These palm fronds were used to make fans and cool rice, as can be seen in Clause 23 below.
[Lotus Leaves]
div.p:
Lotus leaves:
75 young lotus leaves; the white portion of the stalk, four and a half stems 〈to be used from mid-fifth month to mid-sixth month〉.
75 fully grown leaves; lotus seeds, 20 clusters; 15 lotus roots 〈for late sixth month through the late seventh month.〉
75 yellow leaves; lotus seeds, 20 clusters; 15 lotus roots 〈for the early eighth month through the late ninth month.〉
The above is to be sent as offerings from Kawachi Province, and they are to be presented on every other day [of the month] for each of these periods.

div.note: [Items for Making the Royal Meal Throughout the Year]
div.p: For the year: 3 silk covers for the sovereign's rice 〈2 silk covers of silk floss are to be separated into 5 ton of silk floss. 1 silk cover is to be 3 ton 1 ryō 2 shu . All have a length of 2 jō 5 shaku 〉; 1 silk wrapping for hand-pulled noodles 〈length of 7 shaku .〉 4 large silk sieves 〈for the water jug spouts, each with a length of 3 shaku 5 sun 〉; 95 small silk sieves 〈13 for the Hot Soup Preparation Station, 14 for the Pickling Station, 13 for the Sweets Station, 10 for the Milling Station, 7 for the Glutinous Rice Flour Station, 3 for the Oil-making Station; 3 for the Amazura Syrup Station, 8 for the Hishio Station, and 24 for various uses . div.note: These are various preparation spaces needed to supply the royal kitchen system. The Milling Station was specifically for processing wheat and barley. Amazura syrup is made by squeezing Japanese ivy, boiling it, and straining it.
Cloth treated with oil would allow it to be waterproof.
div.p: 24 bleached hemp ropes for 12 royal meal chests 〈length of 1 jō , to be divided in half [to twelve], and replaced twice over the course of the year〉; 14 bleached cloth sieves 〈10 large sieves for use at the royal well, each with a length of 3 shaku 5 sun , double-layered, and 4 water sieves, each with a length of 4 shaku 〉; 1 bleached cloth bag for polishing royal rice 〈length 1 jō 〉; 36 towels of bleached cloth 〈For wiping down the silver meal bowls, 12 pieces of cloth, each 2 shaku in length. For making thin dumplings ( usu mochii ) , 2 pieces of cloth, each 1 jō 2 shaku 5 sun in length. For wrapping the hand-pulled noodles, one cloth that is 4 shaku long. For wiping down the royal table, 6 pieces of cloth, each 5 shaku in length. For wiping down the cauldron ( kama ), one cloth that is 4 shaku in length. For wiping down the mortar, 2 pieces of cloth each with a length of 2 shaku 5 sun . For pressing crucian carp, 3 pieces of cloth, each with a length of 2 shaku . For crucian carp that has been grilled and preserved, then pressed, 3 pieces of cloth each with a length of 2 shaku . For wiping out the shallow pot, 5 pieces of cloth, each 5 shaku . To make bags for cooking and drying wheat or barley ( mugi ), 1 piece of cloth with a length of 6 shaku 〉; 3 pieces of fabric for tablecloths 〈For the mochi-making table, 1 piece of cloth with a length of 1 jō 4 shaku . For the Grain Bureau's 2 tables, 2 pieces of cloth, each with a length of 6 shaku . For covering the stove pots, 12 pieces of bleached cloth 〈each with a length of 1 shaku 5 sun 〉;
div.note: The Banquet Protocols informs us that this item would be made with wheat flour and flavored with hishio .
div.p: raw silk, 3 ku 〈for embroidering the tablecloth and for the strainer〉; scoured silk thread, 1 bu 2 shu 〈for embroidering the rice covering〉; 3 whetstones 〈for sharpening the knives〉; 28 palm fronds 〈8 leaves for fanning the rice and 20 leaves for fanning the cooking fires〉; hemp, 6 kin 3 ryō 〈24 pieces of string for the stoves, and it takes 4 ryō 3 shu to make 1 piece〉;

5 Continental chests 〈4 are for holding hishio , vinegar, and miso, as well as pickles; 1 chest is for holding rice〉; 24 transport tables 〈3 tables are for the chests of various dishes, 2 tables are for holding fish, 4 tables are for holding the chests of various sweets, 4 tables are for the containers used to wash vegetables, 3 tables are for presenting the chests of various fish, 2 tables are for aemono chests, 3 tables are for the royal rice chest, 3 tables are spares〉; 16 cutting board tables 〈2 tables are for preparing aemono , 2 tables are for preparing side dishes, 2 tables are for various preparations of arame kelp, 2 tables are for preparing various produce, 4 tables are for preparing fresh fish, 2 tables are for preparing various sweets, and 2 tables are spares〉;
div.note: These were chests with legs.
These transport tables were for carrying dishes. Once food dishes were placed on the transport table, group of people would carry the table to the dining location to serve the food.

Aemono is a general category of preparation, not unlike a salad in the American sense of the word, with chopped vegetables, fish, herbs, and such that are dressed with condiments like miso, vinegar, sesame, or mustard.
div.p: 8 large tubs 〈4 tubs are for washing various pickled vegetables, 1 tub is for washing various sweets, 1 tub is for washing the vegetables to make soup, 2 tubs are for washing tablecloths and other cloths〉; 13 round tubs 〈2 tubs are for washing various raw produce, 5 tubs are for washing pickled ginger, 2 tubs are for washing various fresh fish, 2 tubs are for washing various produce, 2 are for washing [produce for] aemono 〉;

4 wooden mortars 〈2 for grinding salt and elm , 2 for grinding flour〉; 8 pestles 〈for grinding various things〉; 5 winnows 〈2 for separating salt and elm, 3 are for winnowing rice flour〉; 190 dried gourds 〈for ladling various liquids〉;
div.note: These mats were made of woven grass, not unlike blinds, and they could be laid out as seating. Here we can see how they were used in food preparation.
div.p: vinegar jars and hishio jars, 30 of each; 8 bowls; 4 portable jars ; 8 large jars; 8 small jars; 8 rounded square jars; 4 Sue pottery mortars 〈the above is for presenting the eight types of aemono 〉; 12 washing bowls 〈4 are for polishing rice, 8 are for washing the various sake lees pickles〉; 12 bucket dishes 〈4 are for pickling dishes for the royal meal, 8 are for holding the sake lees and miso〉; 20 motai jars 〈10 are for holding the hishio and the various hishio pickles, 10 are for holding the various sake lees pickles〉; 8 tsubo jars 〈for holding hishio pickles and sake lees pickles〉;11 shallow pots 〈for scooping water〉; 16 yuka jars 〈for scooping water from〉; 2 tataibe jars 〈for the water leftover from washing the rice〉; 2 lamp lids 〈for covering lamps〉;

The sacred jars, or yuka , were type of large Sue pottery jar used in offering water and sake to the kami and sovereign. The first character has implications for kami-related ritual, but these jars appeared to be used widely for storing water and sake around the palace.
div.p: 47 plain chests 〈4 are for holding pots of atsumono soup, 4 are for holding pickles in liquid, 2 are for holding washed produce, 6 are for holding various fish, 3 are for holding side dishes, 4 are for holding various aemono vessels, 4 are for holding oak [leaves], 4 are for holding vegetables, 16 are for general preparation〉; 57 plain wood boxes 〈12 are for cooling rice, 4 are for holding washed aemono [produce], 4 are for holding washed vegetables for soup, 37 are for general preparation〉; 20 boxes 〈2 are for holding daikon radish, 4 are for holding mochi, 4 are for holding delicacies, 4 are for holding shitoki mochi , 2 are for holding knives, 4 are for holding fruits〉; 38 round chests 〈for holding various items and to be sent from the Royal Provisions Hall to the Royal Meal Station〉;
div.note: A type of mochi made from steamed white rice and clean water.

The Royal Provisions Hall ( Niedono ) was a building used for organizing royal provisions, or minie , sent from the provinces to be used by the Royal Meal and Banquet offices. Officials working in this hall would also be handling the foods produced at the tributary lands ( kuriya ).
div.p: 77 knives 〈10 are for shucking oysters, 4 are for chopping up sea lettuce, 2 are for cutting abalone, 2 are for chopping up Ecklonia cava seaweed, 2 are for chopping or removing fish bones, 1 is for making mochi strips, 1 is for konton steamed dumplings, 55 are for various uses. 20 long knives. 35 short knives〉;

10 tables 〈4 are for making various sweets , 2 are for placing royal meal chests, 2 are for placing royal tables, 2 are for the contents of the royal meal〉; 2 high tables 〈for cooling and drying bowls used by the sovereign〉; 7 water jug tables;
div.note: Here, “sweets” means confections, as well as processing or drying fruits and nuts.
div.p: bleached hemp cloth, 9 tan 2 jō 9 shaku 〈2 tan 1 jō 6 shaku is for 10 towels, and each piece should be 1 jō . The 3 jō 6 shaku is for the 2 cooks making mochi strips who receive cloth for outer robes, and each piece is to have a length of 1 jō 8 shaku . 1 tan 4 shaku is to be used for 11 clothing cords each with a length of 4 shaku . 1 jō 2 shaku is for 2 chihaya jackets, and each is to have a length of 6 shaku . 1 tan 2 jō 3 shaku for the 13 workers' chihaya jackets, each with a length of 5 shaku . 1 tan 1 jō 8 shaku is for the 10 palace servants' chihaya jackets, each with a length of 6 shaku . 1 jō 8 shaku is for the 4 serving women's chihaya jackets, each with a length of 4 shaku 5 sun . 1 tan 1 jō 4 shaku is for 4 outer robes' cloth, each with a length of 1 jō 4 shaku . 8 shaku is for 4 hats, each with a length of 2 shaku .〉

div.note: [Various Implements for the Royal Meal]
div.p:
Various implements for the royal meal: 4 red lacquer standing trays 〈2 are for daily use and 2 are for royal banquets〉; 2 black lacquer standing trays 〈for purification ( kessai )〉; various vessels of gold, silver, red lacquer, and glazed stoneware.
The above is to be requested by the Royal Secretariat ( Kurōdo dokoro ). However, for daily items, such as the 2 jō 5 shaku 2 sun of oiled silk for covering the 2 standing trays, when these items are damaged, new ones are to be received from the Palace Storehouse Bureau.

5 red lacquer bowls 〈each is to be 3 sun 5 bu deep, and the rim is to have a diameter of 1 shaku 1 sun .〉 The queen-consort and the crown prince are to have three bowls each. 5 Kondōkai writing desks 〈each is to be 1 shaku high and have a diameter of 8 sun .〉 The queen-consort and crown prince are to have three each.
The above is to be used daily and at royal banquets. In the event that they are broken, they are to be replaced.
div.note: These were writing desks used at banquets.
div.p:
3 transport chests 〈for the sovereign, queen-consort, and crown prince's daily use〉; 4 long chests 〈for transporting various produce during Obon and the royal banquets〉; 2 transport tables 〈for choosing produce〉; 1 sake tub 〈for washing produce〉 ; 1 portable water jug 〈to draw water from when washing the produce〉; cloth, 1 tan 〈2 jō to make chihaya jackets and clothing cords for the two men choosing and washing the produce. 2 jō 2 shaku are for fastening the lids on the 4 transport chests〉.
The above is to be requested and used each year. However, the long chests and the sake tub are to be requested once every three years.

div.note: [The Cloth Used for Harvesting and Collecting Fruits and Grains]
div.p: 4 tan of yōfu tax cloth goes towards the harvest cloth ( katabira ) to be used for gathering fruit or drying various grains. This is to be requested once after three years.

div.note: [For the Red Label of Approval ( shime no ake no hata )]
div.p: Various offerings are to be marked with a red banner of approval of 16 ryū 〈each is to be 1 shaku 9 sun long and 5 sun 5 bu wide.〉 Each year, the Royal Meal Office is to receive this from the Female Chamberlains Office. The Female Chamberlains Office is to stamp the cloth with the seal.
div.note: This red banner of approval is a literal translation of the characters used. This cloth was marked with a seal. In the ninth and tenth centuries, the red banner came to function as a purifying force for those involved in tribute for the sovereign's meals as fears arose around pollution ( kegare ) in the food's production and sourcing.
[For making cowpea dumplings ( fuzuku )]
div.p:
For making cowpea dumplings: white rice, 4 koku ; cowpeas, 1 koku 8 to ; light thin for bags to use for wringing the flour and water strainers, 2 of each 〈the bags are to be 6 shaku long each and the strainers' diameters are to be 1 shaku 5 sun each〉; 1 piece of bleached cloth that is used for curtains for drying the flour 〈length 3 jō 〉; 1 piece of bleached cloth for covering the water jug 〈length of 4 shaku 〉; for cooking the dumplings , 2 bleached cloth bags 〈6 shaku long each〉; 1 water jug; 1 sake tub; 2 yuka jars; 1 dried gourd for carrying water; 2 mats; 2 frames with slats; 30 kin of firewood for each day making the dumplings.
The above is to be served from the first day of the third month to the thirtieth day of the eighth month.
div.note: It is not clear how this item might be made. This verb here can be interpreted as “to lift,” the dumplings while cooking, but how the bag is being used to lift dumplings is also unclear. The bags could contain the dumplings and be boiled, bag and all in the water, or the bags could be placed in the water strainer and possibly steamed and the bag used to lift the batch.
[Offerings of Various Produce]
div.p:
Offerings of various produce: For one day, 1 to . For aemono , 3 shō ; 30 melons 〈equivalent to 3 shō and to be sent from the fifth month through the eighth month〉; 40 eggplants 〈equivalent to 2 shō and to be sent in the sixth, seventh, eighth, and ninth months〉; amaranth, 4 shō 〈fifth, sixth, seventh, and eighth months〉; 6 stalks of thistle 〈equivalent to 6 shō and to be sent from the second month through the ninth month〉; 2 bundles of butterbur 〈equivalent to 2 shō , fifth, sixth, seventh, and eighth months〉; 4 stalks of turnips 〈equivalent to 4 shō and from the New Year through the twelfth month〉; 4 bundles of crucifer greens 〈equivalent to 4 shō , second month through third month〉; Shepard's purse 4 shō 〈first, second, eleventh, and twelfth months〉; 4 bundles of lettuce 〈equivalent to 2 shō , third, fourth, and fifth months〉; 4 bundles of mallow 〈equivalent to 2 shō , fifth, eighth, ninth, and tenth months〉; 4 bundles of dock 〈equivalent to 2 shō , fourth, fifth, eighth, ninth, and tenth month〉; 2 bundles of Chinese chives 〈equivalent to 2 shō , second month through the ninth month〉; 2 bundles of spring onion 〈equivalent to 1 shō , first, fourth, fifth, ninth, tenth, eleventh, and twelfth months〉; 100 stalks of garlic 〈equivalent to 2 shō , in the first, second, third, fourth, eleventh, and twelfth months it is to be sent fresh. In the fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth, and ninth months, it is to be dried and sent〉;
8 hands of raw ginger 〈equivalent to 2 shō , sixth, seventh, and eighth months〉; Japanese pepper, 2 gō 〈young leaves in the third and fourth months, the pepper seed in the fifth and sixth months〉; 10 bundles of water pepper 〈equivalent to 2 shō , fourth month through the ninth month〉; 2 bundles of long stamen chives ( araragi ) 〈equivalent to 1 shō , from the first month to the twelfth month〉; coriander, 2 gō 〈first, second, ninth, tenth, eleventh, and twelfth months〉; 4 bundles of daikon radish 〈equivalent to 4 shō , first, second, tenth, eleventh, and twelfth months〉; 4 bundles of water celery 〈equivalent to 4 shō , first month through sixth month〉; 4 bundles of water leeks 〈equivalent to 4 shō , fifth, sixth, seventh, and eighth months〉; 2 bundles of taro stems 〈sixth, seventh, eighth, and ninth months〉;
div.note: Hiru , the name for this plant is a general term for aromatic herbs like chives or garlic. Because this passage says to send both fresh and dried versions at different times of year, this may be garlic. There is also a possibility that hiru refers to the stalk and root while araragi below refers to the greens of the plant.
This is likely wild chives or another aromatic relative. This may refer to a specific part of a plant, like the greens.
div.p: various fruits, 5 shō ; raw soybeans and adzuki beans, 6 bundles of each 〈sixth, seventh, eighth, and ninth months〉; raw cowpeas, 6 bundles 〈sixth and seventh months〉; cudweed, 5 shō 〈second and third month〉; taros, 4 shō 〈first, ninth, tenth, eleventh, and twelfth months〉; 8 ripe melons 〈sixth, seventh, and eighth months〉; chestnuts, 3 shō 〈seventh, eighth, and ninth months〉; peaches, 4 shō 〈seventh, eighth, and ninth months〉; 10 yuzu 〈ninth and tenth months〉; persimmons, 2 shō 〈ninth, tenth, and eleventh months〉; 10 bunches of loquats 〈fifth and sixth months〉; plum, 2 shō 〈fifth and sixth months〉; bramble-berries , 2 shō 〈fifth month〉; 4 bamboo shoots 〈fifth and sixth months〉. These are to be provided to the queen-consort.
div.note: Ichigo at this time referred to some kind of bramble-berry or wild strawberry.
div.p: 5 shō of various produce is to be sent to the crown prince: aemono , 2 shō ; various fruits, 3 shō ; raw soybeans, adzuki beans, and cowpeas, 3 bundles of each; cudweed and taro, 2 shō of each; chestnuts 1 shō ; peaches 2 shō ; 5 yuzu; persimmons and plums, 1 shō of each; 10 clusters of loquats; 2 bamboo shoots.

div.note: [Fresh Produce for the Seven Annual Royal Banquets ]
div.p: 1 koku 5 to 9 gō of fresh produce for each of the seven annual royal banquets 〈5 to 1 shō to the Director of the Royal Meal Office, the same amount to the queen-consort, and 2 to 4 shō 9 gō to the crown prince〉.
div.note: Royal banquets ( sechie ) were banquets attended personally by the monarch.
[The Yamashina Garden Early Melons]
div.p: On the fifth day of the fifth month, the Yamashina Garden is to make an offering of early melons . 〈If there are no early melons, send the flower buds〉.
div.note: Melon vines, such as cucumbers or winter melons, grow male and female flowers. If melons were still just beginning to grow after pollination, it would be fine for growers to pluck the male flowers and send them to the palace without destroying the future melon crop.
[Annual Produce]
div.p: Various produce for the year, 84 koku 4 to

div.note: [Produce Quantity]
div.p: The amount of produce offered during the year should not be expressed in to , but in the number of pieces ( koku ). The amount is to be determined by the Royal Meal Office Director and the office receiving the produce.

div.note: [Various Produce for Royal Visits]
div.p: For royal visits, the various produce is to be provided in advance.

The above is the produce for making spring pickles.

Melons, 8 koku 〈requires salt, 4 to 8 shō 〉; sake lees pickled melon, 9 to 〈requires salt, 1 to 9 shō 8 gō ; lees liquid, 1 to 9 shō 8 gō ; hishio lees, 2 to 7 shō ; hishio , 2 to 7 shō 〉; hishio -pickled melon, 9 to 〈requires salt, hishio , and hishio lees, 1 to 9 shō 8 gō of each〉; lees-pickled winter melon, 1 koku 〈requires salt, 2 to 2 shō , and lees liquid, 4 to 6 shō 〉; hishio -pickled winter melon, 4 to 〈requires salt, 8 shō 8 gō ; hishio , hishio lees, and miso, 1 to 6 shō 8 gō of each〉; leaf mustard with elm bark powder, 3 koku 〈requires salt, 2 to 4 shō , and elm, 1 to 5 shō 〉; fermented turnip , 6 koku 〈requires salt, 6 shō ; and soybeans, 1 to 5 shō 〉; turnip with elm bark powder, 10 koku 〈requires salt, 8 shō and elm, 5 shō 〉; ground turnip, 5 to 〈requires salt, 3 shō 〉; fermented turnip stems, 1 koku 〈requires salt, 6 shō , and rice, 5 shō 〉; hishio turnip, 3 to 〈requires salt, 5 shō 4 gō ; and hishio lees 1 to 5 shō 〉; sake lees turnip, 5 to 〈requires salt, 9 shō ; and lees liquid, 1 to 5 shō 〉; sliced turnip with elm powder, 1 koku 4 to 〈requires salt, 2 shō 4 gō and elm, 2 shō 〉;

div.p:
eggplants, 5 koku 〈requires salt, 3 shō 〉; hishio eggplant, 6 to 〈requires salt, 1 to 2 shō ; lees liquid, miso, and hishio lees, 1 to 8 shō of each〉; sake lees eggplant, 6 to 〈requires salt, 1 to 2 shō ; liquid lees, 1 to 8 shō 〉; pickled black nightshade with elm bark powder, 6 to 〈requires salt, 6 shō and elm bark powder, 2 shō 4 gō 〉; pickled black nightshade, 3 to 〈requires salt, 9 shō 〉; water leek, 10 koku 〈requires salt, 7 shō 〉; sake lees pickled pickerel weed, 1 koku 〈requires salt, 1 to 2 shō ; and lees liquid, 5 to 〉; araragi with elm bark powder, 3 to 〈requires salt 2 shō 4 gō , and elm, 1 shō 2 gō 〉; soybeans, 6 to 〈requires salt, 6 shō , and liquid lees, 1 to 8 shō 〉; Magnolia kobus, 2 to 〈requires salt, 4 shō 〉; water pepper with elm bark powder, 4 to 〈requires salt, 4 shō , and elm, 1 shō 6 gō 〉; foxnuts, 1 koku 5 to 〈requires salt, 1 to 5 shō : rice, 7 shō 5 gō 〉; Japanese ginger (myōga), 6 to 〈requires salt, 6 shō , and lees liquid, 2 to 4 shō 〉; young ginger, 3 to 〈requires salt, 6 shō , and lees liquid,1 to 5 shō 〉; ground honeylocust pods, 3 to 〈requires salt, 4 shō 5 gō 〉; silver vine fruit, 2 to 〈requires salt, 2 shō 〉; chocolate vine, 1 to 〈requires salt, 2 shō 2 gō 〉; peaches, 2 koku 〈requires salt, 1 to 2 shō 〉; persimmons, 5 shō 〈requires salt, 2 shō 〉; pears, 6 shō 〈requires salt, 3 shō 6 gō 〉; Japanese pepper 1 koku 〈requires salt 2 to 4 shō 〉; perilla leaves, 6 to 〈requires melons, 9 to ; winter melon, 7 to ; eggplant, 6 to ; turnip, 4 to ; salt, 1 to 2 shō ; hishio , miso, hishio lees, 1 koku of each.〉

Raw ginger, 4 koku 5 to 〈requires salt, 1 koku 4 to 2 shō , and lees liquid, 4 koku 2 to 〉; 35 bundles of beech wood 〈for covering the shallow pots〉; 2 dried gourds 〈for carrying liquids.〉 50 lower level female officials ( nyoju ) and 12 female servants ( nyotei ) are to handle the pickled ginger, and they are to receive half of the supplemental food allotted to a person 〈each day, each person receives 8 gō .〉
Requests are to be sent to the Female Chamberlains Office to receive the necessary ingredients for making pickled ginger throughout the year. In the third month of the following year, depending on the pickling remaining, the amounts of salt and sake lees are to be determined. 〈For instance, if 1 koku of pickled ginger remains, the additional salt provided would be 1 to and the sake lees would be 5 to .〉 From the ninth month to the seventh month of the following year, these pickles are to be served in the royal meal.

div.note: [For Elm Bark Powder]
div.p:
Elm bark, 1000 pieces 〈each to have a length of 1 shaku 5 sun , width of 4 sun .〉 When the bark is ground, this yields 2 koku of powder 〈1 piece yields 2 gō .〉
The above is to be used for making soup ( atsumono ) and the various side dishes for the year.

div.note: [Yamashiro and Yamato Provinces]
div.p: Yamashiro Province 〈magnolia kobus, 2 to 〉; Yamato Province 〈dried bracken, 4 tan . The above is to be sent annually.〉

div.note: [For Salt-Preserved Fish]

div.note: [For Salt-Preserved Fish]
div.p: For making various fermented fish, 10 koku : 6 to of salt-preserved fish for making the fermented fish 〈to be sent from E tributary land in Kawachi Province〉; Exchange cloth, 16 tan ; Shinano hemp, 100 kin ; white rice, 2 koku ; salt, 2 koku 2 to .

div.note: [For Making Crucian Carp]
div.p: For making hishio crucian carp and fermented crucian carp, 10 koku of each; salt-preserved crucian carp, 3 koku 4 to 〈to be sent from Tsukuma tributary land in Ōmi Province〉; 30 motai jars; shōfu exchange cloth, 18 tan ; Shinano hemp, 100 kin ; sake, 5 to ; rice, 1 koku ; salt, 8 koku ; hishio soybeans, 2 koku 5 to .

div.note: [Royal Provisions ( minie ) to be Sent from the Various Provinces]
div.p:
Royal Provisions are to be sent from the various provinces 〈the queen-consort's follows this as well〉.
Offerings to be sent every ten days ( shun no ryō ).
Pigeon from the Yoshino royal tributary land in Yamato Province is to be sent from the ninth month to the fourth month in the following year. Fermented and fire-dried sweetfish are to be sent from the fourth month through the eighth month, and for the first and last ten days of the month there are to be 3 person-loads of each. However, libertina snails as well as big-scaled redfin fish gelatin are to be increased and sent depending on what is caught.
From the ninth month to the third month of the following year for the first and last ten days of each month, the royal tributary land in Shima Province is to send fresh abalone and sazae sea snails, 2 person-loads of each. Each month, preserved [abalone], fermented innards, steamed abalone, dried abalone strips, dried abalone spirals, and summer abalone are to total 5 person-loads. Various fish, 13 person-loads 〈everything is to be conveyed by corvée labor〉.
The various fish of Wakasa Province, 7 person-loads of each, are to be sent for the first and last ten days of the month. 〈The 116 taxable laborers ( kachō ) under the command of the director are to exchange the tax items ( chōmotsu ) received from Wakasa Province for fresh foods, which are to be then conveyed by corvée labor.〉
The various fish, 3.5 tan , from Kii Province is to be sent for the first, middle, and last ten days of the month 〈74 of the same tax laborers are to exchange tax items for fresh foods, which will then be conveyed by corvée labor.〉 The various fish from Awaji Province is 2.5 person-loads 〈for ten days.〉
div.note: “Person-loads,” or tan , was an amount that was thought to be manageable for one person to carry.
div.p:
For the royal banquets:
Yamashiro, Yamato, Kawachi, Izumi, Settsu, Ōmi 〈New Year's Day, first month seventh day's [White Horse Royal Banquet], first month sixteenth day's [Song and Dance Royal Banquet], fifth month fifth day's royal banquet, seventh month seventh day's [banquet], ninth month ninth day's [Double Yang Banquet], Great Harvest Rite Royal Banquet of the eleventh month: for each date there is to be 7 loads. Tax rice in provincial storehouses ( shōzei ) are to be traded for the necessary items and conveyed by corvée labor.〉
Shima Province 〈New Year's Day and the Great Harvest Rite's royal banquets: 8 person-loads ( tan ) each. The first month seventh day, first month sixteenth day, fifth month fifth day, seventh month seventh day, and ninth month ninth day: 3 person-loads for each of these royal banquets.〉
Mikawa Province 〈3 person-loads for each of the three royal banquets of the first month〉; Wakasa Province 〈10 person-loads for the three royal banquets of the first month〉; Kii and Awaji Provinces 〈5 person-loads for each of the three royal banquets of the first month.〉
As to the above, Mikawa Province is to send pheasants. Other provinces are to send various fresh, delicious ingredients. Additionally, Ōmi Province is to include boar and deer to its shipments for the first day. All ingredients below sent every ten days are to be stored at the Royal Meal Office's facilities and served at the prescribed events.

div.note: [Awaji Province Royal Provisions]
div.p: The royal provisions from Awaji Province are for the queen-consort and the three royal banquets in the first month of the year.

div.note: This was a tax levied on men viewed as being in their prime working years. Originally this meant men aged seventeen to twenty, but this was changed in the mid-eighth century to be men from eighteen to twenty-one.
This refers to a method used to catch fish where bamboo or wooden stakes are arranged in the water to trap the fish. This was considered one part of making pillar-caught sweetfish.
These items combined with hishio appears to have been a specialty of the Shuchūshi 主厨司, the Dazaifu office that prepared banquets for foreign visitors.
div.p: The above shows the offerings of the various provinces. When these are served, they are to be taken by the Royal Provisions Hall to be used to make food for the royal table. 〈However, the nibe croakers are to be given to the Royal Meal Office.〉

div.note: [Yamashiro Province Royal Provisions]
[For Whitebait]
div.p: From each of the locations in Yamashiro and Ōmi Provinces that catch whitebait, they are to send whitebait starting from the ninth month through the twelfth month thirtieth day.

div.note: [Mikawa and Tosa Provinces]
div.p: Mikawa Province sea squirts, 1 koku . Tosa Province fermented innards and small abalone, 4 motai jars 〈one motai jar contains 3 to .〉 Each year these are to be exchanged for and sent.

div.note: [Izu Province]
div.p: Izu Province is to offer up approximately 1 koku 4 to 6 shō of bonito for making infused soups. This is to come as a men's t ax item.

div.note: [Royal Tributary Lands' Schedule]
div.p:
The schedule for provinces' royal tributary land offerings:
Izumi Province 〈Rat and Snake [days]〉
Kii Province 〈Ox, Horse, and Rooster [days]〉
Awaji Province 〈Tiger, Sheep, and Dog [days]〉
Ōmi Province 〈Rabbit [days]〉
Wakasa Province 〈Dragon, Monkey, and Boar [days]〉
The offerings listed below are to be sent on each appointed day. An itinerary is to be made in advance and executed on time.
div.note: This schedule is based on the sixty-day cycle organized around the zodiac cycle.
[Oak Leaves for Plating]
div.p: Yamashiro Province is to send 1 load of fresh oak leaves everyday for the sovereign's meals 〈50 bundles of leaves〉 starting from the fifth month fifth day through the eleventh month fourth day. Tanba Province is to send 1 load of dried oak leaves every day starting on the eleventh month fifth day and ending on the fifth month fourth day. The Residential Palace's portion is to be included here as well.

div.note: [Wooden Trays]
div.p: 120 wooden trays. 〈For various uses in the kitchens ( tsukuri dokoro ). The Carpentry Bureau is to send these every year.〉

div.note: [On Making Utensils]
div.p: 2 people to make wooden vessels 〈one person from the Royal Provisions Hall, 1 person from the [Royal Meal] Office.〉 9 people to make earthenware. Each month, 1 person is to make 30 plain wood chests, 780 pieces of earthenware 〈large dishes, medium dishes, deep dishes, flat dishes, saucers, corner plates, hotogi jars, pots, etc.〉 The person making the earthenware is to be paid 9 tan of shōfu exchange cloth 〈for making clay vessels.〉 9 hoes 〈old hoes are to be submitted when requesting new ones〉. Food payments for one person per day amount to 2 shō of brown rice and 2 shaku of salt. They are to receive 4 jō 5 shaku of plain-weave silk in the summer and in the winter, 1 hiki 3 jō of plain-weave silk and 4 ton of silk floss as seasonal clothing payments.
div.note: This rice is actually written as “black rice” 黒米. However, instead of meaning a modern black grain of rice, this actually means that the rice is relatively unpolished. Workers of lower status ate less polished rice.
[Food Payments]
div.p: The food payments for the 30 cooks are 1 shō of white rice and 1 shaku of salt, per person per day. The food payments for the 17 laborers are 2 shō of brown rice and 2 shaku of salt, per person per day. The 40 cooks are to receive clothing.

div.note: [Cloth Payments]
div.p: For the 17 laborers, 1 ryō of dark blue cloth for outer robes 〈2 jō each〉; chōfu tax cloth for hakama trousers, 1 koshi 〈7 shaku each〉; 1 piece of chōfu tax cloth for obi sashes 〈each to have a length of 8 shaku 4 sun at half the standard width.〉 They are to receive this once every three years.

div.note: [Royal Tribute Land Corvée Labor]
div.p: Yamashiro, Kawachi, Settsu, and Izumi provinces are to send corvée laborers to the royal tribute lands of E and Abiko. 40 people for E and 50 people for Abiko.

div.note: [Tsukuma Royal Tribute Land Head]
div.p: The head of the Tsukuma royal tribute land is to be selected from the cooks.

div.note: [Corvée Labor Exemptions]
div.p: From among the cooks with over ten years of service, one is to be considered for exemption from corvée labor ( kanjaku ) after three years.
div.note: Kanjaku refers to the practice of the Popular Affairs Ministry checking records to determine position and whether one would be exempt from corvée labor.
[Laborers' Payments]
div.p: When cooks and male and female laborers are absent, their payment depends on their role within the [Royal Meal] Office.

div.note: [Oxen for the Gardens]
div.p: The 11 oxen used in the gardens are to come from the Bureau of the Left and Right Stables. When oxen die or become old, new ones are to be requested from the [Royal Household] Ministry. After the Council of State has confirmed the request, they are to receive the oxen. Among the 74 hoes provided, 40 of them are hoe shafts, and 34 are spade shafts. They are to be replaced once every two years. 〈Old hoes are to be exchanged.〉 2 horse hoes 〈Old ones are to be exchanged.〉 2 Ox-drawn spades, 4 blades 〈If the above are damaged, they are to be requested.〉 2 carts 〈To be replaced every year.〉

div.note: [Garden Laborers]
div.p: Garden laborers, 14 people 〈1 overseer, 13 workers〉

div.note: [The River Boat]
div.p: 1 river boat 〈length of 3 jō 〉 is to be kept at Yodo Harbor . This boat is to be used for transporting the various produce for the royal table from the Nara and Naki gardens.
div.note: This harbor was likely located on the Yodo River.

460 Various fruit trees 〈100 tsugi pear trees , 100 peach trees, 40 citrus trees, 40 small citrus trees, 100 persimmon trees, 20 tachibana orange trees, 30 large jujube trees, 30 chocolate vines.〉 Bramble-berry garden, 2 tan .
